questions.text: Which of the following statements about the anatomical and developmental aspects of the pinna (auricle) is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: The entire pinna and outer cartilaginous external auditory canal are composed of a single piece of yellow elastic cartilage.

options.label: B
options.text: The area of the pinna devoid of cartilage, known as the incisura terminalis, is utilized in Lempert’s endaural approach to ear surgery.

options.label: C
options.text: The lobule of the ear pinna, which contains fat covered by skin, is an area devoid of cartilage and often used for fat grafts.

options.label: D
options.text: Improper fusion between the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches during embryological development results in the formation of pre-auricular sinuses, which always require surgical excision, regardless of symptomatology.

questions.correct_answer: D. Improper fusion between the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches during embryological development results in the formation of pre-auricular sinuses, which always require surgical excision, regardless of symptomatology.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Improper fusion between the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches during embryological development results in the formation of pre-auricular sinuses, which always require surgical excision, regardless of symptomatology.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pre-auricular sinuses do not always require surgical excision. Treatment is based on the presence of symptoms such as recurrent infections.

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding atrophic rhinitis?

options.label: A
options.text: Atrophy of nerve elements cause merciful anosmia

options.label: B
options.text: Nasal mucosa appears pale due to atrophy

options.label: C
options.text: Turbinate bones resorption causes widening of cavity

options.label: D
options.text: Diseased mucosa removed in Young’s operation

questions.correct_answer: D. Diseased mucosa removed in Young’s operation
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Diseased mucosa removed in Young’s operation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Atrophy of nerve elements cause merciful anosmia:
  • • Option A. Atrophy of nerve elements cause merciful anosmia:
  • • This statement is True: Atrophic rhinitis involves the atrophy of the nasal mucosa, which can lead to damage of the olfactory nerve elements, resulting in anosmia (loss of sense of smell). The term "merciful anosmia" is used because the loss of smell can be considered beneficial to the patient, as it spares them from the unpleasant odor associated with the condition.
  • • This statement is True: Atrophic rhinitis involves the atrophy of the nasal mucosa, which can lead to damage of the olfactory nerve elements, resulting in anosmia (loss of sense of smell). The term "merciful anosmia" is used because the loss of smell can be considered beneficial to the patient, as it spares them from the unpleasant odor associated with the condition.
  • • True:
  • • Option B. Nasal mucosa appears pale due to atrophy:
  • • Option B. Nasal mucosa appears pale due to atrophy:
  • • This statement is True: In atrophic rhinitis, the nasal mucosa becomes pale and thin due to the chronic atrophic process affecting the mucous membrane.
  • • This statement is True: In atrophic rhinitis, the nasal mucosa becomes pale and thin due to the chronic atrophic process affecting the mucous membrane.
  • • True:
  • • Option C. Turbinate bones resorption causes widening of cavity:
  • • Option C. Turbinate bones resorption causes widening of cavity:
  • • This statement is True: The resorption of the turbinate bones in atrophic rhinitis leads to an abnormally wide nasal cavity, which is a characteristic feature of the disease.
  • • This statement is True: The resorption of the turbinate bones in atrophic rhinitis leads to an abnormally wide nasal cavity, which is a characteristic feature of the disease.
  • • True:
  • • Option D. Diseased mucosa removed in Young’s operation:
  • • Option D. Diseased mucosa removed in Young’s operation:
  • • This statement is False: Young’s operation is a surgical procedure used to treat atrophic rhinitis, but it does not involve the removal of the diseased mucosa. Instead, it involves the closure of the nostrils to create a moist environment, which helps in the regeneration of the atrophic mucosa. The operation aims to control the symptoms by reducing the drying effect on the nasal passages.
  • • This statement is False: Young’s operation is a surgical procedure used to treat atrophic rhinitis, but it does not involve the removal of the diseased mucosa. Instead, it involves the closure of the nostrils to create a moist environment, which helps in the regeneration of the atrophic mucosa. The operation aims to control the symptoms by reducing the drying effect on the nasal passages.
  • • False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Young's operation for atrophic rhinitis involves nostril closure to regenerate mucosa, not removing diseased mucosa.

questions.text: A patient with a history of recurrent ear discharge over several years now presents with diplopia and retro-orbital pain. options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Retro-orbital pain is due to involvement of petrous apex

options.label: C
options.text: Gradenigo triad includes diplopia, discharge, and retro-orbital pain

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: A. Diplopia is due to involvement of trochlear nerve
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Diplopia is due to involvement of trochlear nerve

  • • Option A. Diplopia is due to involvement of trochlear nerve:

The abducens nerve is more likely to be affected because it passes through the Dorello’s canal close to the petrous apex of the temporal bone.
  • • This statement is False: In Gradenigo’s syndrome, diplopia is typically due to the involvement of the abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI), not the trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV). The abducens nerve is more likely to be affected because it passes through the Dorello’s canal close to the petrous apex of the temporal bone.
  • • False:
  • • Option B. Retro-orbital pain is due to involvement of petrous apex:
  • • Option B. Retro-orbital pain is due to involvement of petrous apex:
  • • This statement is True: Retro-orbital pain in this condition is caused by inflammation or infection extending to the petrous apex of the temporal bone, a condition known as petrositis.
  • • This statement is True: Retro-orbital pain in this condition is caused by inflammation or infection extending to the petrous apex of the temporal bone, a condition known as petrositis.
  • • True:
  • • Option C. Gradenigo triad includes diplopia, discharge, and retro-orbital pain
  • • Option C. Gradenigo triad includes diplopia, discharge, and retro-orbital pain
  • • This statement is True: Gradenigo’s syndrome is characterized by a classic triad of symptoms: persistent ear discharge (otorrhea), retro-orbital pain, and diplopia (due to abducens nerve involvement).
  • • This statement is True: Gradenigo’s syndrome is characterized by a classic triad of symptoms: persistent ear discharge (otorrhea), retro-orbital pain, and diplopia (due to abducens nerve involvement).
  • • True:
  • • Option D. Definite surgical management is required in this condition
  • • Option D. Definite surgical management is required in this condition
  • • This statement is True: Gradenigo’s syndrome usually requires surgical intervention to address the underlying infection and prevent complications. This often involves procedures such as mastoidectomy to remove the infected tissue and ensure proper drainage.
  • • This statement is True: Gradenigo’s syndrome usually requires surgical intervention to address the underlying infection and prevent complications. This often involves procedures such as mastoidectomy to remove the infected tissue and ensure proper drainage.
  • • True:

  • ➤ In Gradenigo’s syndrome, diplopia is due to abducens nerve involvement, not the trochlear nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding sinusitis?

options.label: A
options.text: Chronic sinusitis is defined as inflammation of the sinuses lasting less than 12 weeks.

options.label: B
options.text: Maxillary sinusitis is the least common type in adults due to the high position of the ostium.

options.label: C
options.text: Frontal sinusitis typically causes pain over the occipital area or vertex.

options.label: D
options.text: Ethmoid sinusitis is common in children and causes pain over the root of the nose and deep to the eye.

questions.correct_answer: D. Ethmoid sinusitis is common in children and causes pain over the root of the nose and deep to the eye.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ethmoid sinusitis is common in children and causes pain over the root of the nose and deep to the eye.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: Chronic sinusitis is defined as inflammation of the sinuses lasting more than 12 weeks.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. False: Maxillary sinusitis is the most common type in adults due to the ostium's location being higher than the floor level, causing drainage against gravity.
  • • Option B. False:
  • • Option C. False: Frontal sinusitis typically causes pain over the frontal area and medial canthus area, not the occipital area or vertex.
  • • Option C. False:
  • • Option D. True: Ethmoid sinusitis is common in children and causes pain over the root of the nose and deep to the eye.
  • • Option D. True:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ethmoid sinusitis is common in children and presents with pain over the root of the nose and deep to the eye.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with poorly controlled diabetes presents with unilateral nasal obstruction, thick nasal discharge, and proptosis. CT scan reveals bone erosion in the maxillary sinus. Biopsy shows fungal hyphae consistent with Aspergillus fumigatus. What is the most appropriate management for this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Observation and follow-up

options.label: B
options.text: Oral antibiotics and nasal decongestants

options.label: C
options.text: Antifungal therapy and surgical debridement

options.label: D
options.text: Corticosteroids and antihistamines

questions.correct_answer: C. Antifungal therapy and surgical debridement
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Antifungal therapy and surgical debridement

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: Observation and follow-up are not appropriate for invasive fungal sinusitis, which requires prompt treatment.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. False: Oral antibiotics and nasal decongestants are not effective against fungal infections and do not address the bone erosion and potential complications of invasive aspergillosis.
  • • Option B. False:
  • • Option C. True: Invasive aspergillosis, especially in immunocompromised patients, requires antifungal therapy (e.g., voriconazole) and surgical debridement with functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) to remove the infected tissue and prevent further complications.
  • • Option C. True:
  • • Option D. False: Corticosteroids and antihistamines are not appropriate treatments for invasive fungal infections.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Invasive fungal sinusitis, particularly in immunocompromised patients, requires prompt treatment with antifungal therapy and surgical debridement to prevent serious complications such as bone erosion and orbital invasion.

questions.text: A patient presents with severe nasal bleeding following a road traffic accident, unresponsive to both anterior and posterior nasal packing. What is the correct sequence of arterial ligation to control the hemorrhage?

options.label: A
options.text: Maxillary → sphenopalatine → greater palatine → anterior ethmoidal

options.label: B
options.text: Sphenopalatine → maxillary → greater palatine → posterior ethmoidal

options.label: C
options.text: Sphenopalatine → maxillary → external carotid → anterior ethmoidal

options.label: D
options.text: Sphenopalatine → maxillary → external carotid → posterior ethmoidal

questions.correct_answer: C. Sphenopalatine → maxillary → external carotid → anterior ethmoidal
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Maxillary → sphenopalatine → greater palatine → anterior ethmoidal
  • • Option A. Maxillary
  • • sphenopalatine
  • • greater palatine
  • • anterior ethmoidal
  • • This sequence is incorrect because the maxillary artery is typically not ligated first. The sphenopalatine artery is usually addressed first due to its significant contribution to nasal blood supply.
  • • This sequence is incorrect because the maxillary artery is typically not ligated first. The sphenopalatine artery is usually addressed first due to its significant contribution to nasal blood supply.
  • • Option B. Sphenopalatine → maxillary → greater palatine → posterior ethmoidal
  • • Option B. Sphenopalatine
  • • maxillary
  • • greater palatine
  • • posterior ethmoidal
  • • This sequence includes the greater palatine artery, which is not commonly ligated in this context. Additionally, the posterior ethmoidal artery is less likely to be a primary target in severe nasal bleeding.
  • • This sequence includes the greater palatine artery, which is not commonly ligated in this context. Additionally, the posterior ethmoidal artery is less likely to be a primary target in severe nasal bleeding.
  • • Option C. Sphenopalatine → maxillary → external carotid → anterior ethmoidal
  • • Option C. Sphenopalatine
  • • maxillary
  • • external carotid
  • • anterior ethmoidal
  • • This is the correct sequence. The sphenopalatine artery is the primary source of blood supply to the nasal cavity, and its ligation is the first step. If bleeding persists, the maxillary artery is next, followed by the external carotid artery. The anterior ethmoidal artery is ligated last if needed.
  • • This is the correct sequence. The sphenopalatine artery is the primary source of blood supply to the nasal cavity, and its ligation is the first step. If bleeding persists, the maxillary artery is next, followed by the external carotid artery. The anterior ethmoidal artery is ligated last if needed.
  • • Option D. Sphenopalatine → maxillary → external carotid → posterior ethmoidal
  • • Option D. Sphenopalatine
  • • maxillary
  • • external carotid
  • • posterior ethmoidal
  • • While this sequence is mostly correct, the posterior ethmoidal artery is not typically targeted over the anterior ethmoidal artery, which is more commonly involved in nasal bleeding.
  • • While this sequence is mostly correct, the posterior ethmoidal artery is not typically targeted over the anterior ethmoidal artery, which is more commonly involved in nasal bleeding.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In severe nasal bleeding unresponsive to packing, the sequence for arterial ligation is sphenopalatine, maxillary, external carotid, and then anterior ethmoidal arteries.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of uncontrolled diabetes presents with facial pain, black eschars on his palate, and nasal congestion. He recently recovered from COVID-19 and had been treated with high-dose steroids. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the recommended treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Bacterial sinusitis; oral antibiotics and nasal decongestants

options.label: B
options.text: Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis; corticosteroids and antifungal therapy

options.label: C
options.text: Mucormycosis; surgical debridement and IV amphotericin B

options.label: D
options.text: Chronic sinusitis; nasal irrigation and systemic corticosteroids

questions.correct_answer: C. Mucormycosis; surgical debridement and IV amphotericin B
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mucormycosis; surgical debridement and IV amphotericin B

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: Bacterial sinusitis does not present with black eschars and requires different management.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. False: Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis is less aggressive and does not typically present with black eschars or rapid tissue invasion.
  • • Option B. False:
  • • Option C. True: Mucormycosis, caused by Mucor and Rhizopus species, presents with black eschars, especially in immunocompromised patients like uncontrolled diabetics. The recommended treatment is urgent surgical debridement and IV amphotericin B.
  • • Option C. True:
  • • Option D. False: Chronic sinusitis typically presents with long-term inflammation and congestion without the acute, aggressive presentation of black eschars seen in mucormycosis.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mucormycosis, an aggressive fungal infection caused by Mucor and Rhizopus species, presents with black eschars and rapid tissue invasion in immunocompromised patients. The treatment includes surgical debridement and IV amphotericin B.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with chronic sinusitis that has not responded to medical management. She undergoes Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS). Post-operatively, she develops sudden vision loss and proptosis. What is the most likely cause, and what is the immediate management?

options.label: A
options.text: Injury to the nasolacrimal duct; saline irrigation

options.label: B
options.text: CSF rhinorrhea; bed rest and antibiotics

options.label: C
options.text: Anterior ethmoidal artery injury; immediate orbital decompression (lateral canthotomy)

options.label: D
options.text: Frontal mucocele; surgical drainage

questions.correct_answer: C. Anterior ethmoidal artery injury; immediate orbital decompression (lateral canthotomy)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anterior ethmoidal artery injury; immediate orbital decompression (lateral canthotomy)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: Injury to the nasolacrimal duct would cause epiphora, not sudden vision loss and proptosis.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. False: CSF rhinorrhea would present with clear nasal discharge, not sudden vision loss and proptosis.
  • • Option B. False:
  • • Option C. True: Injury to the anterior ethmoidal artery during FESS can cause bleeding that increases pressure in the orbit, leading to sudden vision loss and proptosis. Immediate orbital decompression (lateral canthotomy) is necessary to relieve the pressure and prevent permanent vision loss.
  • • Option C. True:
  • • Option D. False: A frontal mucocele can cause orbital displacement, but it would not present with acute sudden vision loss and proptosis immediately post-operatively.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Complications of Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS) include anterior ethmoidal artery injury, which can cause increased pressure in the orbit, leading to sudden vision loss and proptosis. Immediate management involves orbital decompression through lateral canthotomy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding nasal polyposis and associated conditions?

options.label: A
options.text: Sampter triad includes asthma, nasal polyposis, and bronchiectasis.

options.label: B
options.text: Kartagener syndrome is characterized by recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and infertility due to azoospermia.

options.label: C
options.text: Young syndrome includes recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus.

options.label: D
options.text: The Bernoulli phenomenon in the nose describes how increased air velocity in the middle meatus can lead to the formation of nasal polyps.

questions.correct_answer: D. The Bernoulli phenomenon in the nose describes how increased air velocity in the middle meatus can lead to the formation of nasal polyps.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) The Bernoulli phenomenon in the nose describes how increased air velocity in the middle meatus can lead to the formation of nasal polyps.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: Sampter triad includes asthma, nasal polyposis (ethmoidal), and aspirin hypersensitivity.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. False: Kartagener syndrome is characterized by recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus, not infertility due to azoospermia.
  • • Option B. False:
  • • Option C. False: Young syndrome includes recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and infertility due to azoospermia, not situs inversus.
  • • Option C. False:
  • • Option D. True: The Bernoulli phenomenon describes how increased air velocity in the narrow region of the middle meatus can drag the surrounding mucosa into the nasal cavity, forming nasal polyps.
  • • Option D. True:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Bernoulli phenomenon in the nose explains how increased air velocity in the narrow middle meatus can lead to the formation of nasal polyps by dragging the surrounding mucosa into the nasal cavity.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding nasal polyposis?

options.label: A
options.text: Ethmoidal polyps are typically single and unilateral, originating from the maxillary sinus.

options.label: B
options.text: Antrochoanal polyps are allergic in etiology, multiple, and bilateral.

options.label: C
options.text: The Crescent sign (Dodd sign) helps differentiate antrochoanal polyps from tumors that originate from the pharyngeal wall.

options.label: D
options.text: Concha bullosa can be confirmed by passing a probe all around the structure.

questions.correct_answer: C. The Crescent sign (Dodd sign) helps differentiate antrochoanal polyps from tumors that originate from the pharyngeal wall.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The Crescent sign (Dodd sign) helps differentiate antrochoanal polyps from tumors that originate from the pharyngeal wall.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: Ethmoidal polyps are typically multiple and bilateral, allergic in etiology, and originate from the ethmoidal sinuses.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. False: Antrochoanal polyps are typically single and unilateral, originating from the maxillary sinus, and can be infectious or allergic in etiology.
  • • Option B. False:
  • • Option C. True: The Crescent sign (Dodd sign) is seen as a small air column between the posterior nasopharyngeal wall and the antrochoanal polyp, helping to differentiate it from tumors that originate from the pharyngeal wall.
  • • Option C. True:
  • • Option D. False: Concha bullosa is a hypertrophied middle turbinate and cannot be passed around by a probe, which can be passed around a polyp.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ethmoidal polyps are multiple and bilateral with an allergic etiology, while antrochoanal (Killian's) polyps are single and unilateral, often originating from the maxillary sinus. The Crescent sign helps differentiate antrochoanal polyps from pharyngeal wall tumors.

options.label: A

  • • This sequence is incorrect. The first image shows a vocal nodule, not Reinke’s edema.
  • • Option D. Vocal granuloma, Reinke’s edema, Vocal nodule, Vocal polyp
  • • Option D. Vocal granuloma, Reinke’s edema, Vocal nodule, Vocal polyp
  • • This sequence is incorrect.
  • • This sequence is incorrect.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with unilateral, clear, watery nasal discharge that occurs when he bends his head forward. He reports a sweet taste and inability to sniff the discharge back. What is the most likely diagnosis, and which test can confirm the presence of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Allergic rhinitis; RAST test

options.label: B
options.text: Vasomotor rhinitis; saccharine test

options.label: C
options.text: CSF rhinorrhea; Beta-2 transferrin test

options.label: D
options.text: Chronic sinusitis; nasal endoscopy

questions.correct_answer: C. CSF rhinorrhea; Beta-2 transferrin test
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) CSF rhinorrhea; Beta-2 transferrin test

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: Allergic rhinitis presents with symptoms such as sneezing, itching, and clear nasal discharge, but it does not typically present with unilateral discharge or inability to sniff the discharge back. The RAST test is used to identify specific allergens.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. False: Vasomotor rhinitis involves chronic nasal congestion and rhinorrhea without a clear trigger and does not present with the specific characteristics of CSF rhinorrhea. The saccharine test assesses mucociliary clearance.
  • • Option B. False:
  • • Option C. True: CSF rhinorrhea presents with unilateral, clear, watery discharge that occurs with head movement or straining, a sweet taste, and inability to sniff the discharge back. The Beta-2 transferrin test is specific for confirming the presence of CSF in the nasal discharge.
  • • Option C. True:
  • • Option D. False: Chronic sinusitis involves persistent sinus inflammation and purulent nasal discharge. Nasal endoscopy can help diagnose sinusitis but is not specific for confirming CSF rhinorrhea.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CSF rhinorrhea is characterized by unilateral, clear, watery nasal discharge that occurs with head movement or straining, has a sweet taste, and cannot be sniffed back. The Beta-2 transferrin test is specific for confirming the presence of CSF in the nasal discharge.

questions.text: A newborn presents with difficulty breathing and feeding, which improves when crying. Examination reveals unilateral mucoid nasal discharge and failure to pass a catheter from the nose to the pharynx. What is the most likely diagnosis and the initial management strategy?

options.label: A
options.text: Bilateral choanal atresia; immediate tracheostomy

options.label: B
options.text: Unilateral choanal atresia; feeding nipple with a large hole

options.label: C
options.text: Nasal polyposis; antihistamines and nasal steroids

options.label: D
options.text: Congenital dacryocystocele; surgical repair

questions.correct_answer: B. Unilateral choanal atresia; feeding nipple with a large hole
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Unilateral choanal atresia; feeding nipple with a large hole

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: Bilateral choanal atresia would present with severe respiratory distress and requires more immediate airway management. Unilateral cases are more common and less severe.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. True: Unilateral choanal atresia presents with unilateral nasal discharge and failure to pass a catheter. Initial management includes using a feeding nipple with a large hole (McGovern’s technique) to provide an adequate oral airway.
  • • Option B. True:
  • • Option C. False: Nasal polyposis presents with nasal obstruction and discharge but does not cause failure to pass a catheter from the nose to the pharynx in newborns.
  • • Option C. False:
  • • Option D. False: Congenital dacryocystocele presents with a bluish cystic swelling below the medial canthus and does not affect nasal patency or cause failure to pass a catheter.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Unilateral choanal atresia, the most common type, presents with unilateral nasal discharge and failure to pass a catheter from the nose to the pharynx. Initial management includes using a feeding nipple with a large hole to ensure adequate oral airway until definitive surgical repair can be performed.

questions.text: The following coronal section of CT PNS is taken at which level:

options.label: A
options.text: 1-1.5 cms behind the anterior end of the inferior turbinate

options.label: B
options.text: 1-1.5 cms behind the posterior end of the inferior turbinate

options.label: C
options.text: 1-1.5 cms behind the posterior end of the middle turbinate

options.label: D
options.text: 1-1.5 cms behind the anterior end of the middle turbinate

questions.correct_answer: A. 1-1.5 cms behind the anterior end of the inferior turbinate
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1-1.5 cms behind the anterior end of the inferior turbinate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The arrows in the pic point towards the nasolacrimal duct which lies 1.25 cms behind the anterior end of inferior turbinate.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the laryngeal framework?

options.label: A
options.text: The thyroid cartilage forms a 120-degree angle in males and a 90-degree angle in females.

options.label: B
options.text: The thyroid cartilage is the smallest of all laryngeal cartilages

options.label: C
options.text: The thyrohyoid membrane has openings on both sides for the entrance of superior laryngeal vessels and the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.

options.label: D
options.text: The vocal ligaments arise from the thyroid cartilage and attach to the cricoid cartilage.

questions.correct_answer: C. The thyrohyoid membrane has openings on both sides for the entrance of superior laryngeal vessels and the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The thyrohyoid membrane has openings on both sides for the entrance of superior laryngeal vessels and the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: The thyroid cartilage forms a 90-degree angle in males and a 120-degree angle in females.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. False: The thyroid cartilage is the largest of all laryngeal cartilages.
  • • Option B. False:
  • • Option C. True: The thyrohyoid membrane has openings on both sides for the entrance of superior laryngeal vessels and the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve into the larynx.
  • • Option C. True:
  • • Option D. False: The vocal ligaments arise from the arytenoid vocal processes and attach to the thyroid cartilage anteriorly at the anterior commissure with the help of Broyle’s ligament.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The thyrohyoid membrane has openings on both sides for the entrance of superior laryngeal vessels and the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve into the larynx.

questions.text: A 40-year-old glass-blower presents with hoarseness of voice and a visible swelling in the neck that increases with Valsalva maneuver. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Laryngocele

options.label: B
options.text: Vocal cord polyp

options.label: C
options.text: Cricothyroid membrane tear

options.label: D
options.text: Dysphonia plica ventricularis

questions.correct_answer: A. Laryngocele
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Laryngocele

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. True: A laryngocele is a distension of the saccule of the larynx, which can present with hoarseness and a neck swelling that increases with Valsalva maneuver. It is commonly seen in professions that involve frequent high-pressure breathing, such as glass-blowers.
  • • Option A. True:
  • • Option B. False: Vocal cord polyps typically present with hoarseness but not with a swelling that changes with Valsalva maneuver.
  • • Option B. False:
  • • Option C. False: A cricothyroid membrane tear would present with pain and potential airway compromise but not with a swelling that increases with Valsalva maneuver.
  • • Option C. False:
  • • Option D. False: Dysphonia plica ventricularis refers to voice production by the false vocal cords, which causes hoarseness, but it does not explain the swelling.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laryngocele is a distension of the saccule of the larynx, often seen in individuals who use high-pressure breathing, such as glass-blowers. It presents with hoarseness and a neck swelling that increases with Valsalva maneuver.

questions.text: Dodd sign is absent in juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma because:

options.label: A
options.text: JNA arises from posterior pharyngeal wall

options.label: B
options.text: JNA arises from sphenopalatine foramen

options.label: C
options.text: JNA spreads submucosally from its point of origin

options.label: D
options.text: JNA do not have muscular contractile part in its blood vessels

questions.correct_answer: C. JNA spreads submucosally from its point of origin
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) JNA spreads submucosally from its point of origin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • JNA arises from sphenopalatine foramen and spreads submucosally towards posterior pharyngeal wall side as well as towards the pterygopalatine fossa side. In the submucosal space of posterior pharyngeal space, this tumour enlarges and bulges forwards. Hence, there will not be any Dodd sign here. Even though b and d options are correct, they do not justify the absence of Dodd sign.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the muscles acting on the larynx?

options.label: A
options.text: The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle acts as an adductor of the vocal cords.

options.label: B
options.text: The cricothyroid muscle functions as a tensor of the vocal cords.

options.label: C
options.text: The interarytenoid (oblique part) muscle acts as an opener of the laryngeal inlet.

options.label: D
options.text: The sternohyoid muscle is an elevator of the larynx

questions.correct_answer: B. The cricothyroid muscle functions as a tensor of the vocal cords.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The cricothyroid muscle functions as a tensor of the vocal cords.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle acts as an abductor of the vocal cords.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. True: The cricothyroid muscle functions as a tensor of the vocal cords.
  • • Option B. True:
  • • Option C. False: The interarytenoid (oblique part) muscle acts as a closer of the laryngeal inlet.
  • • Option C. False:
  • • Option D. False: The sternohyoid muscle is a depressor of the larynx.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cricothyroid muscle functions as a tensor of the vocal cords, increasing tension and pitch during phonation.

questions.text: A patient presents with hoarseness of voice following thyroid surgery. Which nerve is most likely damaged, and what is its primary motor function?

options.label: A
options.text: Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (IBSLN); supplying cricothyroid muscle

options.label: B
options.text: External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN); supplying intrinsic muscles of the larynx

options.label: C
options.text: Recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN); supplying all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except cricothyroid

options.label: D
options.text: Vagus nerve; supplying all intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the larynx

questions.correct_answer: C. Recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN); supplying all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except cricothyroid
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN); supplying all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except cricothyroid

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (IBSLN) provides sensory innervation above the level of the vocal cords.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. False: The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN) supplies the cricothyroid muscle, not all intrinsic muscles of the larynx.
  • • Option B. False:
  • • Option C. True: The recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) supplies all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid muscle. Damage to this nerve during thyroid surgery can result in hoarseness.
  • • Option C. True:
  • • Option D. False: The vagus nerve gives rise to both the superior laryngeal nerve and the recurrent laryngeal nerve but does not directly supply all intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the larynx.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) supplies all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid muscle, and its damage during thyroid surgery can result in hoarseness of voice.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with breathy voice and difficulty phonating. Laryngoscopy reveals one vocal cord lying in an intermediate (cadaveric) position while the other vocal cord appears normal. What is the most likely diagnosis and the appropriate initial management?

options.label: A
options.text: Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) palsy; emergency tracheostomy

options.label: B
options.text: Unilateral superior laryngeal nerve (SLN) palsy; observation

options.label: C
options.text: Unilateral RLN+SLN palsy; medialization procedure

options.label: D
options.text: Bilateral superior laryngeal nerve (SLN) palsy; voice therapy

questions.correct_answer: C. Unilateral RLN+SLN palsy; medialization procedure
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Unilateral RLN + SLN palsy; medialization procedure

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: Bilateral RLN palsy causes both vocal cords to lie in a paramedian position, leading to airway obstruction and stridor, requiring emergency tracheostomy.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. False: Unilateral SLN palsy alone does not typically cause a vocal cord to lie in the intermediate position; it affects pitch control.
  • • Option B. False:
  • • Option C. True: Unilateral RLN + SLN palsy results in one vocal cord lying in an intermediate (cadaveric) position, causing a breathy voice due to the gap during phonation. Medialization procedures help improve voice quality by reducing this gap.
  • • Option C. True:
  • • Option D. False: Bilateral SLN palsy affects pitch control but does not cause significant airway obstruction or breathy voice that requires such interventions.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) palsy results in one vocal cord lying in an intermediate (cadaveric) position, causing a breathy voice. The initial management typically involves a medialization procedure to improve voice quality by reducing the gap during phonation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Isshiki thyroplasties?

options.label: A
options.text: Type I thyroplasty is used for bilateral vocal cord palsy.

options.label: B
options.text: Type II thyroplasty is used for unilateral vocal cord palsy.

options.label: C
options.text: Type III thyroplasty is used for puberphonia in males after failure of speech therapy.

options.label: D
options.text: Type IV thyroplasty is used for female-to-male transgender conversions.

questions.correct_answer: C. Type III thyroplasty is used for puberphonia in males after failure of speech therapy.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Type III thyroplasty is used for puberphonia in males after failure of speech therapy.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: Type I thyroplasty (medialization thyroplasty) is used for unilateral vocal cord palsy to improve voice by medializing the paralyzed cord.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. False: Type II thyroplasty (lateralization thyroplasty) is used for bilateral vocal cord palsy to lateralize the cords and improve airway patency.
  • • Option B. False:
  • • Option C. True: Type III thyroplasty (shortening thyroplasty) is used for puberphonia in males after failure of speech therapy and for female-to-male transgender conversions.
  • • Option C. True:
  • • Option D. False: Type IV thyroplasty (lengthening thyroplasty) is used for androphonia (masculine voice in females) and male-to-female transgender conversions.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Isshiki thyroplasty type III is used for puberphonia in males after failure of speech therapy and for female-to-male transgender conversions.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with decreased hearing on right side. You have done tuning fork tests and found that Rinne was negative on right side and Weber lateralised to the right ear. Otoendoscopy picture is shown below. Where do you expect the primary pathology? Find the relevant picture in the given options.

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above

questions.correct_answer: D. None of the above
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) None of the above

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Otoendoscopy shows serous otitis media. Unilateral SOM in a 60-year old can be suspected of having nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Hence nasopharynx should be checked for the primary pathology. But, in this question, patient was having right SOM. So, the primary pathology should be checked on right side of nasopharynx. But the picture given in c option is of left nasopharynx. Hence d is the right option.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the anatomical divisions of the larynx and hypopharynx?

options.label: A
options.text: The supraglottis is the area below the vocal cords extending to the beginning of the trachea.

options.label: B
options.text: The glottis is the area at the level of the vocal cords.

options.label: C
options.text: The subglottis is the area above the vocal cords enclosed by the aryepiglottic fold.

options.label: D
options.text: The hypopharynx includes the anterior pharyngeal wall, the pyriform sinus, and the post-cricoid area.

questions.correct_answer: B. The glottis is the area at the level of the vocal cords.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The glottis is the area at the level of the vocal cords.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: The supraglottis is the area above the vocal cords enclosed by the aryepiglottic fold.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. True: The glottis is the area at the level of the vocal cords.
  • • Option B. True:
  • • Option C. False: The subglottis is the area below the vocal cords extending to the beginning of the trachea (upper border of the first tracheal ring).
  • • Option C. False:
  • • Option D. False: The hypopharynx includes the posterior pharyngeal wall, the pyriform sinus, and the post-cricoid area, not the anterior pharyngeal wall.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The larynx is divided into three zones: the supraglottis (above the vocal cords enclosed by the aryepiglottic fold), the glottis (at the level of the vocal cords), and the subglottis (below the vocal cords up to the beginning of the trachea). The hypopharynx includes the posterior pharyngeal wall, the pyriform sinus, and the post-cricoid area.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with difficulty breathing and a hoarse voice. Laryngoscopic examination shows that her vocal cords do not fully abduct during inspiration. Which muscle is most likely impaired, and what is its primary function?

options.label: A
options.text: Lateral cricoarytenoid; adduction of vocal cords during expiration

options.label: B
options.text: Posterior cricoarytenoid; abduction of vocal cords during inspiration

options.label: C
options.text: Transverse arytenoid; adduction of vocal cords during expiration

options.label: D
options.text: Thyroarytenoid; tensing the vocal cords

questions.correct_answer: B. Posterior cricoarytenoid; abduction of vocal cords during inspiration
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Posterior cricoarytenoid; abduction of vocal cords during inspiration

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: The lateral cricoarytenoid muscle is responsible for adduction of the vocal cords during expiration, not abduction during inspiration.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. True: The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is responsible for abduction of the vocal cords during inspiration, allowing the airway to open.
  • • Option B. True:
  • • Option C. False: The transverse arytenoid muscle assists in adduction of the vocal cords during expiration.
  • • Option C. False:
  • • Option D. False: The thyroarytenoid muscle helps in tensing the vocal cords and is not primarily responsible for their abduction during inspiration.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is responsible for the abduction of the vocal cords during inspiration, allowing the airway to open for breathing.

questions.text: A patient has undergone a procedure that is shown in the following picture. BERA test was done after the procedure (sound stimulus was directly given from outside to the processor instead of giving through earphone in ear canal). Which waves will be found abnormal?

options.label: A
options.text: I & II

options.label: B
options.text: V

options.label: C
options.text: III, IV, V, VI & VII

options.label: D
options.text: All waves will be absent

questions.correct_answer: A. I & II
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) I & II

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The picture shows Auditory brainstem implant. It will be done in cases of auditory neuropathy. Pre-operative BERA will show no responses because the sound wave cannot travel through auditory nerve and hence the brainstem nuclei cannot get stimulated. So, all waves will be absent.
  • • After ABSI, the sound waves will directly reach the brainstem bypassing the auditory nerve. Hence the waves corresponding to brainstem nuclei and central cortex (III to VII) will be present. The waves related to eighth nerve will be absent (I & II).

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of high-grade fever, dyspnea, and inspiratory stridor. The child prefers to sit and lean forward. Examination reveals a red and swollen epiglottis. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the initial imaging finding you expect to see?

options.label: A
options.text: Laryngotracheobronchitis; steeple sign on X-ray

options.label: B
options.text: Acute epiglottitis; thumb sign on X-ray

options.label: C
options.text: Foreign body aspiration; hyperinflation of the affected lung on X-ray

options.label: D
options.text: Asthma exacerbation; normal chest X-ray

questions.correct_answer: B. Acute epiglottitis; thumb sign on X-ray
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acute epiglottitis; thumb sign on X-ray

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: Laryngotracheobronchitis (croup) presents with a barking cough and a steeple sign on X-ray, not the clinical presentation described.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. True: Acute epiglottitis is characterized by sudden onset high-grade fever, dyspnea, inspiratory stridor, and a preference to sit leaning forward (tripod sign). The thumb sign on X-ray is a classic finding indicating a swollen epiglottis.
  • • Option B. True:
  • • Option C. False: Foreign body aspiration might show hyperinflation of the affected lung but does not present with the described clinical picture and the thumb sign.
  • • Option C. False:
  • • Option D. False: Asthma exacerbation would not show the thumb sign on X-ray and typically presents with wheezing and a normal chest X-ray.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute epiglottitis presents with sudden onset high-grade fever, dyspnea, inspiratory stridor, and a preference to sit leaning forward (tripod sign). The thumb sign on lateral neck X-ray is a classic finding, indicating a swollen epiglottis.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents with a gradual onset of fever, hoarseness, a barking cough, and inspiratory stridor. Physical examination shows intercostal retractions. An anteroposterior neck X-ray reveals narrowing of the subglottic airway. What is the most likely diagnosis and the characteristic radiographic finding?

options.label: A
options.text: Acute epiglottitis; thumb sign

options.label: B
options.text: Croup (acute laryngotracheobronchitis); steeple sign

options.label: C
options.text: Foreign body aspiration; hyperinflation of the affected lung

options.label: D
options.text: Bacterial tracheitis; ragged tracheal air column

questions.correct_answer: B. Croup (acute laryngotracheobronchitis); steeple sign
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Croup (acute laryngotracheobronchitis); steeple sign

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: Acute epiglottitis presents with a sudden onset of high fever and inspiratory stridor, and the thumb sign is seen on a lateral neck X-ray.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. True: Croup presents with a gradual onset of fever, hoarseness, barking cough, and inspiratory stridor. The characteristic radiographic finding is the steeple sign, indicating narrowing of the subglottic airway.
  • • Option B. True:
  • • Option C. False: Foreign body aspiration might show hyperinflation of the affected lung but does not present with the typical symptoms and signs of croup.
  • • Option C. False:
  • • Option D. False: Bacterial tracheitis can present with a ragged tracheal air column on imaging, but it typically follows a viral upper respiratory infection and is not characterized by the barking cough of croup.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Croup (acute laryngotracheobronchitis) presents in children with a gradual onset of fever, hoarseness, barking cough, inspiratory stridor, and intercostal retractions. The characteristic radiographic finding is the steeple sign on an anteroposterior neck X-ray, indicating subglottic airway narrowing.

questions.text: A patient presented with right sided hardness of hearing. Otoendoscopy and pure tone audiometry were given below. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the condition in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Transformer ratio is decreased after surgery

options.label: B
options.text: Stapedial reflex is intact after surgery

options.label: C
options.text: The contents of the middle ear that are modified in this surgery develop from 1 st pharyngeal arch

options.label: D
options.text: Surgery is contraindicated

questions.correct_answer: D. Surgery is contraindicated
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Surgery is contraindicated

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The presence of schwartz sign in the otoendoscopy picture shows that the otosclerosis is active. Hence, the surgery is contraindicated. (If surgery is attempted, there will be more bleed due to the active disease process and increased vascularity.)
  • • Transformer ratio increases because the diameter of the piston will be around 0.8mm. Hence areal ratio (45mm2 / 0.8mm2) will be increased 4 times when compared to normal areal ratio (45mm2 / 3.2mm2). Lever ratio remains same.
  • • As stapedius tendon is cut during surgery, stapedial reflex is lost after surgery.
  • • The contents of the middle ear that are modified in this surgery develop from 2 nd pharyngeal arch. Stapes suprastructure (which develops from 2 nd arch) is removed. Stapedius tendon (which belongs to 2 nd arch) is cut.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes a difference between the adult and pediatric larynx?

options.label: A
options.text: The pediatric larynx is located at the levels of C3 to C6 vertebrae.

options.label: B
options.text: The adult larynx has an omega-shaped epiglottis.

options.label: C
options.text: The narrowest part of the pediatric larynx is the glottis.

options.label: D
options.text: The pediatric larynx is positioned higher, opposite C1 and C2 vertebrae, allowing infants to simultaneously breathe and suckle.

questions.correct_answer: D. The pediatric larynx is positioned higher, opposite C1 and C2 vertebrae, allowing infants to simultaneously breathe and suckle.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) The pediatric larynx is positioned higher, opposite C1 and C2 vertebrae, allowing infants to simultaneously breathe and suckle.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: The pediatric larynx is located at the levels of C1 to C2 vertebrae, not C3 to C6.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. False: The pediatric larynx has an omega-shaped epiglottis, while the adult larynx has a leaf-shaped epiglottis.
  • • Option B. False:
  • • Option C. False: The narrowest part of the pediatric larynx is the subglottis, not the glottis.
  • • Option C. False:
  • • Option D. True: The pediatric larynx is positioned higher, opposite C1 and C2 vertebrae, allowing infants to breathe and suckle simultaneously by creating an air channel behind the epiglottis.
  • • Option D. True:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The pediatric larynx is positioned higher, opposite C1 and C2 vertebrae, allowing infants to simultaneously breathe and suckle by creating an air channel behind the omega-shaped epiglottis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with hearing loss and occasional ear discharge. Otoscopic examination shows retraction of the pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane. Based on the staging of the retraction of pars flaccida shown in the image, what is the likely stage of this patient if the examination reveals a deep retraction pocket with adherent malleus, but without ossicular erosion?

options.label: A
options.text: Type I

options.label: B
options.text: Type II

options.label: C
options.text: Type III

options.label: D
options.text: Type IV

questions.correct_answer: C. Type III
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Type III

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The stages of pars flaccida retraction are classified based on the extent of retraction and involvement of ossicular chain:
  • • Type 0 (Normal): The pars flaccida is not retracted and appears normal.
  • • Type 0 (Normal):
  • • Option A. Type I: There is a slight retraction of the pars flaccida without touching the ossicles.
  • • Option A. Type I:
  • • Option B. Type II: The retraction pocket touches the neck of the malleus but does not affect other ossicles or their function.
  • • Option B. Type II:
  • • Option C. Type III: The retraction pocket is deeper, involves adhesion of the pars flaccida to the malleus, potentially leading to malleus fixation, but without erosion of the ossicles.
  • • Option C. Type III:
  • • Option Type IV: The retraction is severe with erosion of the ossicular chain, which may lead to more significant hearing loss and other complications.
  • • Option Type IV:
  • • In the scenario described, since the retraction pocket is deep and the malleus is adherent but not eroded, it corresponds to Type III.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identify Type III pars flaccida retraction as characterized by a deep retraction pocket with malleus adhesion but no ossicular erosion.

questions.text: Which of the following congenital anomalies of the larynx presents with inspiratory stridor, cyanosis, and floppy supraglottic structures?

options.label: A
options.text: Subglottic stenosis

options.label: B
options.text: Tracheomalacia

options.label: C
options.text: Laryngomalacia

options.label: D
options.text: Vocal cord paralysis

questions.correct_answer: C. Laryngomalacia
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Laryngomalacia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Laryngomalacia is characterized by excessive flaccidity of the supraglottic structures, particularly the epiglottis and arytenoids. This leads to collapse of the supraglottis during inspiration, causing inspiratory stridor and cyanosis. Stridor typically worsens with crying and improves when the infant is in the prone position. Laryngomalacia usually resolves spontaneously by around 2 years of age as the cartilages of the larynx become more rigid with growth.
  • • Option A. Subglottic stenosis presents with narrowing of the subglottic airway and is not typically associated with floppy supraglottic structures.
  • • Option A. Subglottic stenosis
  • • Option B. Tracheomalacia : involves weakness of the tracheal cartilage, leading to collapse of the trachea during inspiration or expiration. While it can present with stridor, it does not typically cause cyanosis or involve the supraglottic structures.
  • • Option B. Tracheomalacia
  • • Option D. Vocal cord paralysis: can cause stridor, but it typically presents with hoarseness rather than cyanosis, and it does not involve supraglottic collapse.
  • • Option D. Vocal cord paralysis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital anomaly of the larynx, presenting with inspiratory stridor, cyanosis, and floppy supraglottic structures.

questions.text: True or False: Glottic carcinoma typically presents with early symptoms such as change in voice, leading to early diagnosis and a better prognosis.

options.label: A
options.text: True

options.label: B
options.text: False

options.label: C
options.text: True, but prognosis is still poor due to high metastatic potential

options.label: D
options.text: False, but prognosis is better due to less lymphatic spread

questions.correct_answer: A. True
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) True

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Glottic carcinoma involves the vocal cords, resulting in early symptoms such as hoarseness or a change in voice. Patients often present early due to these noticeable symptoms, allowing for prompt diagnosis and treatment at an early stage. Biopsy confirms the diagnosis, and since glottic carcinoma has fewer lymphatics, metastasis is less common, contributing to a better prognosis.
  • • Option B. False: This statement is incorrect. Glottic carcinoma does typically present with early symptoms, leading to early diagnosis and a better prognosis.
  • • Option B.
  • • False:
  • • Option C. True: but prognosis is still poor due to high metastatic potential: This statement is partially correct in acknowledging the early symptoms but incorrectly implies a poor prognosis due to high metastatic potential, which is not typically associated with glottic carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following techniques is the most effective for restoring speech in patients after total laryngectomy?

options.label: A
options.text: Oesophageal speech

options.label: B
options.text: Tracheo-oesophageal speech with artificial prostheses

options.label: C
options.text: Electrolarynx

options.label: D
options.text: Artificial larynx (Chicago implant)

questions.correct_answer: B. Tracheo-oesophageal speech with artificial prostheses
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tracheo-oesophageal speech with artificial prostheses

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Tracheo-oesophageal speech with artificial prostheses, such as the Blom-Singer valve, Provox, or Groningen valve, is the most effective method for restoring speech in patients after total laryngectomy. These devices allow air from the trachea to pass into the oesophagus, where it vibrates the tissues and produces speech.
  • • Option A. Oesophageal speech: involves the patient swallowing air and releasing it to vibrate the pharyngo-oesophageal segment, producing a low sound. While it is a method of speech restoration, it is not as effective or widely used as tracheo-oesophageal speech with prostheses.
  • • Option A. Oesophageal speech:
  • • Option C. Electrolarynx is an electrical device held against the skin of the neck that vibrates and produces voice. It can be used as an alternative method of speech restoration but is not as effective or natural-sounding as tracheo-oesophageal speech with prostheses.
  • • Option C. Electrolarynx
  • • Option D. Artificial larynx (Chicago implant): is not a commonly used method for speech restoration after total laryngectomy.
  • • Option D. Artificial larynx (Chicago implant):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tracheo-oesophageal speech with artificial prostheses, such as the Blom-Singer valve or Provox, is the most effective technique for restoring speech in patients after total laryngectomy.

questions.text: Which condition is characterized by the dislodgement of otoconia into the semicircular canal, leading to vertigo upon changes in head position?

options.label: A
options.text: Meniere's disease

options.label: B
options.text: Labyrinthitis

options.label: C
options.text: Vestibular neuritis

options.label: D
options.text: Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV)

questions.correct_answer: D. Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • BPPV is a condition caused by the dislodgement of otoconia into the semicircular canal, most commonly the posterior canal. This results in vertigo upon changes in head position, typically lasting for a few seconds. The Dix-Hallpike maneuver is performed for diagnosis, and the Epley's maneuver is used for treatment. BPPV is the most common cause of peripheral vertigo.
  • • Option A. Meniere's disease: Meniere's disease is characterized by recurrent episodes of vertigo, hearing loss, tinnitus, and a sensation of fullness in the ear. It is not caused by otoconia dislodgement.
  • • Option A.
  • • Meniere's disease:
  • • Option B. Labyrinthitis: Labyrinthitis is an inflammation of the inner ear, typically presenting with vertigo, hearing loss, and sometimes nausea and vomiting. It is not directly caused by otoconia dislodgement.
  • • Option B.
  • • Labyrinthitis:
  • • Option C. Vestibular neuritis: Vestibular neuritis is characterized by acute vertigo, often associated with nausea and vomiting, but without hearing loss. It is not directly caused by otoconia dislodgement.
  • • Option C.
  • • Vestibular neuritis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV) is characterized by vertigo upon changes in head position due to the dislodgement of otoconia into the semicircular canal, typically the posterior canal, and is diagnosed using the Dix-Hallpike maneuver.

questions.text: Which structural and functional units are responsible for sensing angular movements in the semicircular canals?

options.label: A
options.text: Otoconia

options.label: B
options.text: Maculae

options.label: C
options.text: Hair cells

options.label: D
options.text: Cristae

questions.correct_answer: D. Cristae
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cristae are the structural and functional units located in the ampullated end of each semicircular canal. They are responsible for sensing angular movements, while the gelatinous cupula overlies the crista. Any abnormality of these cristae can lead to vertigo, as they play a crucial role in maintaining balance and detecting changes in head position.
  • • Option A. Otoconia: Otoconia are calcium carbonate crystals present in the otolith organs (saccule and utricle) responsible for sensing linear movements, not angular movements.
  • • Option A.
  • • Otoconia:
  • • Option B. Maculae: Maculae are the sensory structures located in the saccule and utricle responsible for sensing linear movements, not angular movements.
  • • Option B.
  • • Maculae:
  • • Option C. Hair cells: Hair cells are present in the maculae and are responsible for transducing mechanical stimuli into electrical signals, but they are not specifically associated with sensing angular movements.
  • • Option C.
  • • Hair cells:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cristae are the structural and functional units located in the ampullated end of each semicircular canal, responsible for sensing angular movements, crucial for maintaining balance and detecting changes in head position.

questions.text: Match the following clinical descriptions with their respective investigations: (choose whichever is most appropriate) A primipara presenting with one sided hardness of hearing and occasional tinnitus. Clinical examination showed intact tympanic membrane. Rinne was negative on one side and Weber was lateralising towards affected side. A middle aged male presenting with giddiness since 20 days. It was followed by gradual increase in hardness of hearing. Rinne was positive on both sides and weber was lateralising towards normal side. A sense of fullness in the ear was also complained. Occasional tinnitus also occurs which is of roaring type. A preterm newborn child admitted to NICU for 10 days and he was kept on mechanical ventilation for more than 5 days. An elderly male presenting with unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus. Rinne was positive on both sides and weber was lateralising towards normal side. Speech discrimination scores were very poor.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A3, B4, C2, D1

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A3: Otosclerosis
  • • A3: Otosclerosis
  • • Otosclerosis typically presents with symptoms such as hardness of hearing and a negative Rinne test lateralizing to the affected side, where the sound is better heard in the affected ear due to a conductive hearing loss. An audiogram showing Carhart's notch (a specific finding in otosclerosis) is diagnostic.
  • • Otosclerosis typically presents with symptoms such as hardness of hearing and a negative Rinne test lateralizing to the affected side, where the sound is better heard in the affected ear due to a conductive hearing loss. An audiogram showing Carhart's notch (a specific finding in otosclerosis) is diagnostic.
  • • B4: Meniere's Disease
  • • B4: Meniere's Disease
  • • The symptoms described such as giddiness, a gradual increase in hardness of hearing, fullness in the ear, and roaring-type tinnitus are characteristic of Meniere's Disease. Electrocochleography is useful in diagnosing Meniere’s disease by detecting increased fluid pressure in the inner ear.
  • • The symptoms described such as giddiness, a gradual increase in hardness of hearing, fullness in the ear, and roaring-type tinnitus are characteristic of Meniere's Disease. Electrocochleography is useful in diagnosing Meniere’s disease by detecting increased fluid pressure in the inner ear.
  • • C2: High Risk of Deafness in a Newborn
  • • C2: High Risk of Deafness in a Newborn
  • • BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) is essential for assessing auditory nerve function in newborns, especially those with high-risk conditions such as prolonged stay in NICU and mechanical ventilation, which can affect hearing.
  • • BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) is essential for assessing auditory nerve function in newborns, especially those with high-risk conditions such as prolonged stay in NICU and mechanical ventilation, which can affect hearing.
  • • D1: Acoustic Neuroma
  • • D1: Acoustic Neuroma
  • • An elderly male with unilateral hearing loss, poor speech discrimination scores, and a Rinne test positive on both sides but Weber test lateralizing to the normal side is indicative of a retrocochlear pathology like an acoustic neuroma. MRI with contrast is the gold standard for visualizing this tumor.
  • • An elderly male with unilateral hearing loss, poor speech discrimination scores, and a Rinne test positive on both sides but Weber test lateralizing to the normal side is indicative of a retrocochlear pathology like an acoustic neuroma. MRI with contrast is the gold standard for visualizing this tumor.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identify clinical presentations and corresponding diagnostic results for conditions such as Otosclerosis (Carhart's notch on audiometry), Meniere's Disease (assessed with Electrocochleography), high-risk newborn auditory testing (BERA), and Acoustic Neuroma (MRI with contrast). This knowledge will help medical students prepare for diagnosing auditory pathologies effectively.

questions.text: Unilateral vocal cord palsy is associated with: Breathy voice Strangled voice Aphonia High risk of aspiration Slight risk of aspiration No risk of aspiration Paramedian vocal cord position Intermediate vocal cord position Respiratory distress No respiratory difficulty Median vocal cord position

options.label: A
options.text: a, e, h, j

options.label: B
options.text: b, f, i, k

options.label: C
options.text: c, d, h, j

options.label: D
options.text: a, f, g, j

questions.correct_answer: A. a, e, h, j
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) a, e, h, j

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • a. Breathy voice: With unilateral vocal cord palsy, the paralysed vocal cord is unable to approximate fully with the functioning cord, resulting in a gap through which air escapes during phonation. This creates a breathy or whispery voice quality.
  • • a. Breathy voice:
  • • e. Slight risk of aspiration: The slight gap may allow some liquid or food particles to enter the airway, but typically the risk of aspiration is not as high as with bilateral vocal cord palsy.
  • • e. Slight risk of aspiration:
  • • h. Intermediate vocal cord position: In unilateral vocal cord palsy, the affected vocal cord typically assumes an intermediate or paramedian position, known as the cadaveric position. This is not fully lateralized nor completely median.
  • • h. Intermediate vocal cord position:
  • • j. No respiratory difficulty: Most patients with unilateral vocal cord palsy do not experience significant respiratory difficulties as the other vocal cord typically compensates well enough for airway patency.
  • • j. No respiratory difficulty:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. b, f, i, k: is incorrect because strangled voice and median vocal cord position are not typical of unilateral vocal cord palsy, and there is a slight, not no, risk of aspiration. Respiratory distress is also unlikely.
  • • Option B. b, f, i, k:
  • • Option C. c, d, h, j: is incorrect as aphonia (complete loss of voice) and high risk of aspiration are more characteristic of bilateral vocal cord involvement.
  • • Option C. c, d, h, j:
  • • Option D. a, f, g, j: is incorrect because while 'a' and 'j' are correct, 'f' (no risk of aspiration) and 'g' (paramedian position) do not accurately describe the typical outcomes of unilateral vocal cord palsy.
  • • Option D. a, f, g, j:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identify that unilateral vocal cord palsy is characterized by a breathy voice due to air escape during phonation, a slight risk of aspiration, the affected vocal cord in an intermediate position, and no significant respiratory difficulty. This knowledge is crucial for diagnosing and managing patients with suspected vocal cord palsy.

  • • The 3rd cranial nerve (oculomotor nerve) can be involved with further cranial extension of the tumor but is not typically the first nerve affected.
  • • The 3rd cranial nerve (oculomotor nerve) can be involved with further cranial extension of the tumor but is not typically the first nerve affected.
  • • Option B. Cranial nerve IV:
  • • Option B. Cranial nerve IV:
  • • The 4th cranial nerve (trochlear nerve) may also be involved later in the progression of intracranial tumor extension but is not the first nerve to be affected.
  • • The 4th cranial nerve (trochlear nerve) may also be involved later in the progression of intracranial tumor extension but is not the first nerve to be affected.
  • • Option C. Cranial nerve V:
  • • Option C. Cranial nerve V:
  • • The 5th cranial nerve (trigeminal nerve) can be involved with further extension but usually after the 6th cranial nerve.
  • • The 5th cranial nerve (trigeminal nerve) can be involved with further extension but usually after the 6th cranial nerve.
  • • Option D. Cranial nerve VI:
  • • Option D. Cranial nerve VI:
  • • The 6th cranial nerve (abducens nerve) is most commonly the first cranial nerve to be involved when the nasopharyngeal carcinoma extends into the cranium due to its anatomical course and proximity to the tumor site.
  • • The 6th cranial nerve (abducens nerve) is most commonly the first cranial nerve to be involved when the nasopharyngeal carcinoma extends into the cranium due to its anatomical course and proximity to the tumor site.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In nasopharyngeal carcinoma, cranial nerve VI (abducens nerve) is typically the first nerve to be involved when the tumor extends into the cranium.

questions.text: A patient while eating fish felt something suddenly stuck in her throat and came to ER. She is having a pricky sensation in her throat. She was advised an X-ray which is given below. Find the location of foreign body.

options.label: D
options.text: None

questions.correct_answer: D. None
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) None

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • 1 – hyoid bone
  • • 2 – cricoid ossification
  • • 3 – mandible ramus margin
  • • There is no foreign body in this x-ray. Sometimes, the fish bone may traumatise by pricking in the mucosa of the pharynx. Due to local oedema, patient will have a sensation of having something in the throat. But, on x-ray, we may not visualise any foreign body. In that case, just assure the patient and give anti-inflammatory medication. Within 2-3 days, it will get resolved.

questions.text: Which of the following situations does not require immediate management?

options.label: A
options.text: A road traffic accident patient with bilateral nose block and soft, fluctuant swelling

options.label: B
options.text: A completely normal young patient having sudden onset of complete hearing loss and tinnitus on one side

options.label: C
options.text: An elderly male with incontrollable nasal bleed

options.label: D
