questions.correct_answer: D. A road traffic accident patient with swelling on dorsum of nose and fracture nasal bones
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. describes septal hematoma which requires immediate incision and drainage.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B . shows sudden sensorineural hearing loss and it requires immediate intratympanic injection of steroids. The prognosis depends on how early the treatment starts.
  • • Option B
  • • Option C. shows epistaxis due to hypertension (possibly, clue – elderly) and it requires nasal packing.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D . shows fracture nasal bones and the reduction should be done after 5-7 days when the oedema subsides.
  • • Option D

questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of severe nosebleeds and nasal obstruction. On examination, a red, fleshy mass is observed in the nasal cavity. He also has a broad nasal bridge and conductive hearing loss in the right ear. CT imaging shows anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Perform a biopsy of the nasal mass

options.label: B
options.text: Initiate high-dose corticosteroids

options.label: C
options.text: Refer for surgical excision of the tumor

options.label: D
options.text: Administer intranasal vasoconstrictors

questions.correct_answer: C. Refer for surgical excision of the tumor
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Refer for surgical excision of the tumor

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Perform a biopsy of the nasal mass:
  • • Option A. Perform a biopsy of the nasal mass:
  • • This is contraindicated in juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma due to the high vascularity of the tumor, which can lead to uncontrollable bleeding.
  • • This is contraindicated in juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma due to the high vascularity of the tumor, which can lead to uncontrollable bleeding.
  • • Option B. Initiate high-dose corticosteroids:
  • • Option B. Initiate high-dose corticosteroids:
  • • Corticosteroids are not the primary treatment for JNA. The definitive treatment is surgical excision due to the tumor’s potential to cause significant local destruction and complications.
  • • Corticosteroids are not the primary treatment for JNA. The definitive treatment is surgical excision due to the tumor’s potential to cause significant local destruction and complications.
  • • Option C. Refer for surgical excision of the tumor:
  • • Option C. Refer for surgical excision of the tumor:
  • • Surgical excision is the main treatment for juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. The approach to surgery depends on the extent and location of the tumor.
  • • Surgical excision is the main treatment for juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. The approach to surgery depends on the extent and location of the tumor.
  • • Option d: Administer intranasal vasoconstrictors:
  • • Option d: Administer intranasal vasoconstrictors:
  • • While intranasal vasoconstrictors may provide temporary relief from epistaxis, they do not address the underlying tumor and are not a definitive treatment.
  • • While intranasal vasoconstrictors may provide temporary relief from epistaxis, they do not address the underlying tumor and are not a definitive treatment.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most appropriate management for juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is surgical excision due to its high vascularity and potential for significant local spread and complications. Biopsy is contraindicated because of the risk of uncontrollable bleeding.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with dysphagia and a sensation of a lump in his throat. He has a significant smoking history and reports unintentional weight loss over the past three months. A flexible nasoendoscopy reveals a mass in the hypopharynx. Which of the following areas is not a part of the hypopharynx?

options.label: A
options.text: Pyriform sinus

options.label: B
options.text: Postcricoid area

options.label: C
options.text: Posterior pharyngeal wall

options.label: D
options.text: Vallecula

questions.correct_answer: D. Vallecula
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vallecula

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Pyriform sinus:
  • • Option A. Pyriform sinus:
  • • The pyriform sinuses are bilateral recesses in the hypopharynx, located on either side of the laryngeal inlet. They are a common site for hypopharyngeal cancer.
  • • The pyriform sinuses are bilateral recesses in the hypopharynx, located on either side of the laryngeal inlet. They are a common site for hypopharyngeal cancer.
  • • Option B. Postcricoid area
  • • Option B.
  • • Postcricoid area
  • • The postcricoid area is part of the hypopharynx and is located just behind the cricoid cartilage. This region is also a common site for carcinoma.
  • • The postcricoid area is part of the hypopharynx and is located just behind the cricoid cartilage. This region is also a common site for carcinoma.
  • • Option C. Posterior pharyngeal wall
  • • Option C. Posterior pharyngeal wall
  • • The posterior pharyngeal wall is the posterior boundary of the hypopharynx and includes the mucosal surface extending from the base of the tongue to the esophagus.
  • • The posterior pharyngeal wall is the posterior boundary of the hypopharynx and includes the mucosal surface extending from the base of the tongue to the esophagus.
  • • Option D. Vallecula
  • • Option D. Vallecula
  • • The vallecula is not part of the hypopharynx; it is located in the oropharynx. It is the space between the base of the tongue and the epiglottis.
  • • The vallecula is not part of the hypopharynx; it is located in the oropharynx. It is the space between the base of the tongue and the epiglottis.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The hypopharynx consists of the pyriform sinuses, postcricoid area, and posterior pharyngeal wall, while the vallecula is part of the oropharynx.

questions.text: Endoscopic view of larynx picture is given below with numbering of various parts. Of these 4 parts, 3 parts belong to hypopharynx and 1 part does not. Which numbered part does not belong to hypopharynx?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the anatomical features of the pharynx and related structures?

options.label: A
options.text: The sphenopalatine foramen is formed by the perpendicular plate of the ethmoid bone and the palatine bone.

options.label: B
options.text: Passavant’s ridge is formed by the palatopharyngeus and superior constrictor muscles and prevents food from entering the nasopharynx during swallowing.

options.label: C
options.text: The fossa of Rosenmuller lies anterior to the torus tubarius and is a common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

options.label: D
options.text: The pterygopalatine fossa contains the mandibular nerve and the sphenopalatine artery.

questions.correct_answer: B. Passavant’s ridge is formed by the palatopharyngeus and superior constrictor muscles and prevents food from entering the nasopharynx during swallowing.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Passavant’s ridge is formed by the palatopharyngeus and superior constrictor muscles and prevents food from entering the nasopharynx during swallowing.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: The sphenopalatine foramen is formed by the pterygoid part of the sphenoid bone and the perpendicular plate of the palatine bone, not the ethmoid bone.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. True: Passavant’s ridge is a circular ridge of muscular fibers formed by the palatopharyngeus and superior constrictor muscles at the junction of the nasopharynx and oropharynx. It functions to prevent food from entering the nasopharynx during swallowing.
  • • Option B. True:
  • • Option C. False: The fossa of Rosenmuller lies behind the torus tubarius and is indeed a common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma, but it does not lie anterior to the torus tubarius.
  • • Option C. False:
  • • Option D. False: The pterygopalatine fossa contains the maxillary artery, maxillary nerve, and sphenopalatine ganglion, not the mandibular nerve and sphenopalatine artery.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Passavant’s ridge is formed by the palatopharyngeus and superior constrictor muscles at the junction of the nasopharynx and oropharynx, preventing food from entering the nasopharynx during swallowing.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with progressive dysphagia, foul-smelling breath, and a gurgling sound when swallowing. On physical examination, a left-sided neck swelling is noted, and palpation of this swelling produces a gurgling sound. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Achalasia

options.label: B
options.text: Zenker’s diverticulum

options.label: C
options.text: Esophageal carcinoma

options.label: D
options.text: Schatzki ring

questions.correct_answer: B. Zenker’s diverticulum
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Zenker’s diverticulum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Achalasia: is a motility disorder characterized by the inability of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax, leading to dysphagia for both solids and liquids, but it does not typically present with halitosis, gurgling sounds, or a neck swelling.
  • • Option A. Achalasia:
  • • Option B. True: Zenker’s diverticulum, or pharyngeal pouch, forms at Killian’s dehiscence between the thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus parts of the inferior constrictor. It commonly presents in older adults with symptoms of dysphagia, halitosis, gurgling sounds, and a left-sided neck swelling. Diagnosis is confirmed by a Barium swallow study.
  • • Option B. True:
  • • Option C. Esophageal carcinoma can cause progressive dysphagia and weight loss but is not typically associated with halitosis, gurgling sounds, or a palpable neck swelling.
  • • Option C. Esophageal carcinoma
  • • Option D. Schatzki ring: is a narrowing at the lower esophagus causing intermittent dysphagia for solids, but it does not present with the additional symptoms of halitosis, gurgling sounds, or neck swelling.
  • • Option D. Schatzki ring:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zenker’s diverticulum, presenting with dysphagia, halitosis, gurgling sounds, and left-sided neck swelling (Boyce sign), is diagnosed by a Barium swallow and treated with excision or Dohlman procedure.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the anatomical gaps between the pharyngeal constrictor muscles and their contents?

options.label: A
options.text: The sinus of Morgagni, a gap between the skull base and the superior constrictor, contains the Eustachian tube, tensor veli palatini muscle, levator veli palatini muscle, and ascending pharyngeal artery.

options.label: B
options.text: The gap between the superior and middle constrictors contains the stylopharyngeus muscle and the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX cranial nerve).

options.label: C
options.text: The gap between the middle and inferior constrictors contains the recurrent laryngeal nerve and the superior laryngeal vessels.

options.label: D
options.text: The gap between the inferior constrictor and the esophagus contains the internal laryngeal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve and the inferior laryngeal vessels.

questions.correct_answer: B. The gap between the superior and middle constrictors contains the stylopharyngeus muscle and the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX cranial nerve).
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The gap between the superior and middle constrictors contains the stylopharyngeus muscle and the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX cranial nerve).

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: The sinus of Morgagni contains the Eustachian tube, tensor veli palatini muscle, levator veli palatini muscle, and ascending palatine artery, not the ascending pharyngeal artery.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. True: The gap between the superior and middle constrictors contains the stylopharyngeus muscle and the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX cranial nerve).
  • • Option B. True:
  • • Option C. False: The gap between the middle and inferior constrictors contains the internal laryngeal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve and the superior laryngeal vessels, not the recurrent laryngeal nerve.
  • • Option C. False:
  • • Option D. False: The gap between the inferior constrictor and the esophagus contains the recurrent laryngeal nerve and the inferior laryngeal vessels, not the internal laryngeal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The gap between the superior and middle constrictors contains the stylopharyngeus muscle and the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX cranial nerve).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the histological features of various salivary gland tumors?

options.label: A
options.text: Pleomorphic adenoma contains both epithelial and lymphoid elements.

options.label: B
options.text: Warthin tumor, also known as adenolymphoma, shows both epithelial and mesenchymal elements on histology.

options.label: C
options.text: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is characterized by the presence of mucin-producing cells and lymphoid cells.

options.label: D
options.text: Adenoid cystic carcinoma, also known as cylindroma, is known for its high rate of infiltration, including perineural and lymphatic spread.

questions.correct_answer: D. Adenoid cystic carcinoma, also known as cylindroma, is known for its high rate of infiltration, including perineural and lymphatic spread.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Adenoid cystic carcinoma, also known as cylindroma, is known for its high rate of infiltration, including perineural and lymphatic spread.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: Pleomorphic adenoma contains both epithelial and mesenchymal elements, not lymphoid elements.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. False: Warthin tumor, also known as adenolymphoma or papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum, shows both epithelial and lymphoid elements on histology.
  • • Option B. False:
  • • Option C. False: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is characterized by the presence of both mucin-producing cells and squamous cells, not lymphoid cells.
  • • Option C. False:
  • • Option D. True: Adenoid cystic carcinoma, also known as cylindroma, is known for its high rate of infiltration, including perineural and lymphatic spread.
  • • Option D. True:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adenoid cystic carcinoma, also known as cylindroma, is characterized by a high rate of infiltration, including perineural and lymphatic spread.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with a 3-day history of fever, anorexia, and swelling of the parotid glands. Initially, the swelling was unilateral but has now become bilateral. He also complains of body aches. Which of the following is the most likely complication of his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Bacterial meningitis

options.label: B
options.text: Orchitis

options.label: C
options.text: Chronic pancreatitis

options.label: D
options.text: Nephrolithiasis

questions.correct_answer: B. Orchitis
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Orchitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: While mumps can cause aseptic meningitis, it does not typically cause bacterial meningitis.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. True: Mumps, caused by the paramyxovirus, commonly presents with parotid swelling, fever, anorexia, and body aches. It can lead to complications such as orchitis, particularly in post-pubertal males.
  • • Option B. True:
  • • Option C. False: Mumps can cause acute pancreatitis but not typically chronic pancreatitis.
  • • Option C. False:
  • • Option D. False: Mumps does not typically cause nephrolithiasis (kidney stones). It can cause nephritis, which is an inflammation of the kidneys.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mumps is a viral infection caused by the paramyxovirus, presenting with parotid swelling, fever, anorexia, and body aches. It can lead to complications such as orchitis, meningitis, pancreatitis, and sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the conditions affecting the oral cavity?

options.label: A
options.text: Ankyloglossia restricts tongue movement due to a backward attachment of the frenulum.

options.label: B
options.text: Oral submucous fibrosis is characterized by excessive collagen deposition, causing a pale whitish appearance and difficulty in mouth opening.

options.label: C
options.text: Ranula is a bluish, translucent swelling in the floor of the mouth that arises due to obstruction of ducts in the submandibular gland.

options.label: D
options.text: Retention cysts of minor salivary glands are most commonly seen in the upper lip and are due to ductal obstruction.

questions.correct_answer: B. Oral submucous fibrosis is characterized by excessive collagen deposition, causing a pale whitish appearance and difficulty in mouth opening.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Oral submucous fibrosis is characterized by excessive collagen deposition, causing a pale whitish appearance and difficulty in mouth opening.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: Ankyloglossia, or tongue-tie, restricts tongue movement due to a forward attachment of the frenulum below the tongue, not backward.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. True: Oral submucous fibrosis involves excessive collagen deposition in the submucosa, leading to a pale whitish appearance and difficulty in mouth opening (trismus) due to fibrotic bands.
  • • Option B. True:
  • • Option C. False: Ranula is a bluish, translucent swelling in the floor of the mouth caused by obstruction of ducts in the sublingual gland, not the submandibular gland.
  • • Option C. False:
  • • Option D. False: Retention cysts of minor salivary glands are most commonly seen in the lower lip, not the upper lip, and result from ductal obstruction.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oral submucous fibrosis is characterized by excessive collagen deposition in the submucosa, leading to a pale whitish appearance and difficulty in mouth opening due to fibrotic bands.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident with significant trauma to his face. On examination, there is swelling and deformity of his nose. Which of the following structures are most likely involved in the lower two-thirds of his external nose?

options.label: A
options.text: Nasal bones and upper lateral cartilages

options.label: B
options.text: Upper lateral and septal cartilages

options.label: C
options.text: Nasal bones and lower lateral (alar) cartilages

options.label: D

questions.explanation:

  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. False: While the upper lateral and septal cartilages are part of the lower two-thirds, this option does not include all the structures involved.
  • • Option B. False:
  • • Option C. False: The nasal bones are part of the upper one-third, and this option does not account for all the cartilages in the lower two-thirds.
  • • Option C. False:
  • • Option D. True: The lower two-thirds of the external nose is formed by the upper lateral, lower lateral (alar), lesser alar (sesamoid), and septal cartilages.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lower two-thirds of the external nose is formed by the upper lateral, lower lateral (alar), lesser alar (sesamoid), and septal cartilages.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with pain and swelling in the entrance of his nasal cavity. He reports that the area is tender and has been progressively getting worse. On examination, you observe a furuncle in the vestibule area. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism and appropriate nerve supply involved?

options.label: A
options.text: Streptococcus pyogenes; branches of the olfactory nerve

options.label: B
options.text: Staphylococcus aureus; branches of the infraorbital nerve

options.label: C
options.text: Pseudomonas aeruginosa; branches of the trigeminal nerve

options.label: D
options.text: Haemophilus influenzae; branches of the facial nerve

questions.correct_answer: B. Staphylococcus aureus; branches of the infraorbital nerve
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Staphylococcus aureus; branches of the infraorbital nerve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: While Streptococcus pyogenes can cause skin infections, the typical causative organism for furuncles in the nasal vestibule is Staphylococcus aureus. The olfactory nerve is responsible for the sense of smell and not the sensation in the nasal vestibule.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. True: Staphylococcus aureus is the most common causative organism for furuncles (boils) in the vestibule area of the nasal cavity. The nerve supply to this area is provided by branches of the infraorbital nerve.
  • • Option B. True:
  • • Option C. False: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is associated with other types of infections, particularly in immunocompromised patients, but is not the typical causative organism for furuncles in the nasal vestibule. The trigeminal nerve provides general sensory innervation but is not specific to this scenario.
  • • Option C. False:
  • • Option D. False: Haemophilus influenzae is not commonly associated with furuncles in the nasal vestibule. The facial nerve is primarily responsible for motor innervation to facial muscles.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Furuncles in the nasal vestibule are typically caused by Staphylococcus aureus and the area is innervated by branches of the infraorbital nerve.

questions.text: Regarding the anatomy of the lateral nasal wall and associated structures, which of the following statements is true?

options.label: A
options.text: The inferior turbinate is a part of the ethmoid bone and attaches to the maxilla and palatine bone.

options.label: B
options.text: The nasolacrimal duct opens into the middle meatus and is guarded by Hasner's valve.

options.label: C
options.text: Pneumatization of the middle turbinate is referred to as concha bullosa.

options.label: D
options.text: The middle turbinate has three parts, one of which lies in the sagittal plane and attaches to the vomer.

questions.correct_answer: C. Pneumatization of the middle turbinate is referred to as concha bullosa.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pneumatization of the middle turbinate is referred to as concha bullosa.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: The inferior turbinate is a separate bone, not a part of the ethmoid bone. It attaches to the maxilla and palatine bone.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. False: The nasolacrimal duct opens into the inferior meatus and is guarded by Hasner's valve.
  • • Option B. False:
  • • Option C. True: Pneumatization of the middle turbinate is referred to as concha bullosa.
  • • Option C. True:
  • • Option D. False: The middle turbinate has three parts, but the part that lies in the sagittal plane attaches to the cribriform plate, not the vomer.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pneumatization of the middle turbinate is referred to as concha bullosa.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the anatomy of the nasal sinuses and turbinates?

options.label: A
options.text: The superior turbinate is part of the sphenoid bone and forms a landmark for the frontal sinus opening.

options.label: B
options.text: The posterior ethmoid air cells open into the sphenoethmoidal recess.

options.label: C
options.text: Pneumatization of the area over the sphenoid posteriorly forms the Onodi cell, which is located close to the optic nerve.

options.label: D
options.text: The drainage of the maxillary sinus depends on the attachment of the uncinate process.

questions.correct_answer: C. Pneumatization of the area over the sphenoid posteriorly forms the Onodi cell, which is located close to the optic nerve.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pneumatization of the area over the sphenoid posteriorly forms the Onodi cell, which is located close to the optic nerve.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: The superior turbinate is part of the ethmoid bone, not the sphenoid bone, and it forms a landmark for the sphenoid ostium opening, not the frontal sinus opening.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. False: The posterior ethmoid air cells open into the superior meatus, not the sphenoethmoidal recess.
  • • Option B.
  • • False:
  • • Option C. True: Pneumatization of the area over the sphenoid posteriorly forms the Onodi cell, which is located close to the optic nerve (Mnemonic: OO = Onodi Optic).
  • • Option C. True:
  • • Option D. False: The drainage of the frontal sinus, not the maxillary sinus, depends on the attachment of the uncinate process.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pneumatization over the sphenoid posteriorly forms the Onodi cell, which lies very close to the optic nerve.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with nasal obstruction and deviation. On examination, you suspect a deviated nasal septum. Which of the following statements about the anatomy of the nasal septum is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The septum proper is formed entirely of the quadrangular cartilage.

options.label: B
options.text: The columellar septum is immovable and consists of bony support.

options.label: C
options.text: The membranous septum consists of a double layer of skin without bony or cartilaginous support.

options.label: D
options.text: The septum proper includes only cartilaginous components and no bony elements.

questions.correct_answer: C. The membranous septum consists of a double layer of skin without bony or cartilaginous support.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The membranous septum consists of a double layer of skin without bony or cartilaginous support.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: The septum proper is made up of various parts of different bones and the quadrangular cartilage, not just the quadrangular cartilage alone.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. False: The columellar septum is movable and consists of the medial crura of the alar cartilages united together by fibrous tissue, not bony support.
  • • Option B. False:
  • • Option C. True: The membranous septum consists of a double layer of skin with no bony or cartilaginous support and lies between the columella and the caudal border of the septal cartilage.
  • • Option C. True:
  • • Option D. False: The septum proper includes both bony elements and cartilaginous components.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The membranous septum consists of a double layer of skin without bony or cartilaginous support and lies between the columella and the caudal border of the septal cartilage.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a sports injury to his nose. He has significant nasal bleeding and swelling. On examination, there is a deviated nasal septum and a suspected hematoma. What is the most appropriate initial management?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate open septo-rhinoplasty

options.label: B
options.text: Immediate nasal packing and incision and drainage of the hematoma

options.label: C
options.text: Immediate reduction of the fracture with Asch forceps

options.label: D
options.text: Observation and reduction after 3 weeks

questions.correct_answer: B. Immediate nasal packing and incision and drainage of the hematoma
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Immediate nasal packing and incision and drainage of the hematoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: Immediate open septo-rhinoplasty is not the initial management for nasal trauma with hematoma and bleeding. This procedure is considered if reduction is delayed for more than 3 months.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. True: The most appropriate initial management for nasal trauma with significant bleeding (epistaxis) and a suspected hematoma is immediate nasal packing to control bleeding and incision and drainage to prevent complications from the hematoma.
  • • Option B.
  • • True:
  • • Option C. False: Immediate reduction with Asch forceps is not recommended if there is significant swelling; reduction may be difficult and should be delayed until the swelling subsides.
  • • Option C. False:
  • • Option D. False: Observation and reduction after 3 weeks is not appropriate for immediate management. Delaying reduction for more than 2-3 weeks leads to callus formation and bone remodeling, making reduction difficult.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Immediate management of nasal trauma with epistaxis and hematoma includes nasal packing to control bleeding and incision and drainage of the hematoma to prevent complications.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department with bilateral nasal obstruction and a sense of pressure over the nasal bridge after a recent nasal trauma. On examination, there is a smooth, rounded, soft, and fluctuant swelling of the septum in both nasal cavities. What is the most appropriate immediate treatment to prevent complications?

options.label: A
options.text: Observation and follow-up in one week

options.label: B
options.text: Immediate packing and systemic antibiotics

options.label: C
options.text: Incision and drainage, followed by packing and antibiotics

options.label: D
options.text: Nasal decongestants and saline irrigation

questions.correct_answer: C. Incision and drainage, followed by packing and antibiotics
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Incision and drainage, followed by packing and antibiotics

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: Observation and follow-up are not appropriate as immediate intervention is required to prevent complications such as cartilage necrosis and septal abscess.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. False: While packing and antibiotics are necessary, incision and drainage of the hematoma are essential to relieve the pressure and prevent complications.
  • • Option B. False:
  • • Option C. True: The most appropriate immediate treatment for a septal hematoma is incision and drainage to remove the collected blood, followed by packing and antibiotics to prevent infection and support healing.
  • • Option C. True:
  • • Option D. False: Nasal decongestants and saline irrigation are not sufficient to address a septal hematoma and prevent complications.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Immediate incision and drainage, followed by packing and antibiotics, are essential to treat a septal hematoma and prevent complications such as cartilage necrosis and septal abscess.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with recurrent nosebleeds. On examination, the bleeding is found to originate from the nasal septum. Which of the following arteries is NOT involved in the blood supply to the nasal septum?

options.label: A
options.text: Anterior ethmoidal artery

options.label: B
options.text: Superior labial artery

options.label: C
options.text: Greater palatine artery

options.label: D
options.text: Inferior alveolar artery

questions.correct_answer: D. Inferior alveolar artery
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Inferior alveolar artery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: The anterior ethmoidal artery, a branch of the ophthalmic artery from the internal carotid system, supplies the nasal septum.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. False: The superior labial artery, a branch of the facial artery from the external carotid system, supplies the nasal septum.
  • • Option B. False:
  • • Option C. False: The greater palatine artery, a branch of the maxillary artery from the external carotid system, supplies the nasal septum.
  • • Option C. False:
  • • Option D. True: The inferior alveolar artery supplies the lower teeth and jaw, not the nasal septum.
  • • Option D. True:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The blood supply to the nasal septum comes from the internal carotid system (anterior and posterior ethmoidal branches of the ophthalmic artery) and the external carotid system (superior labial branch of the facial artery, greater palatine artery, and sphenopalatine branch of the maxillary artery).

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of recurrent nosebleeds presents to the clinic. On examination, you note mucocutaneous telangiectasias on her lips and oral mucosa. She also reports episodes of gastrointestinal bleeding. Given her family history, you suspect Osler-Weber-Rendu disease. Which of the following treatments is being explored for this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Aspirin therapy

options.label: B
options.text: Bevacizumab

options.label: C
options.text: High-dose corticosteroids

options.label: D
options.text: Warfarin

questions.correct_answer: B. Bevacizumab
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bevacizumab

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: Aspirin therapy is not indicated for Osler-Weber-Rendu disease and may exacerbate bleeding tendencies.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. True: Bevacizumab, a recombinant humanized monoclonal antibody against VEGF, is being explored as a treatment option for Osler-Weber-Rendu disease to help manage the vascular abnormalities associated with the condition.
  • • Option B. True:
  • • Option C. False: High-dose corticosteroids are not a standard treatment for Osler-Weber-Rendu disease.
  • • Option C. False:
  • • Option D. False: Warfarin, an anticoagulant, is contraindicated in patients with bleeding disorders like Osler-Weber-Rendu disease.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Osler-Weber-Rendu disease (Hereditary Haemorrhagic Telangiectasia) is an autosomal dominant condition causing recurrent epistaxis, mucocutaneous telangiectasias, and A-V malformations. Treatment options include supportive care, with Bevacizumab being explored for managing vascular abnormalities.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding rhinitis medicamentosa and hypertrophic rhinitis?

options.label: A
options.text: Rhinitis medicamentosa is caused by prolonged use of antihistamines.

options.label: B
options.text: The treatment for rhinitis medicamentosa includes increasing the dose of nasal decongestants.

options.label: C
options.text: Hypertrophic rhinitis is characterized by turbinate hypertrophy due to submucosal fibrosis and is most commonly treated with turbinectomy.

options.label: D
options.text: Hypertrophic rhinitis presents with a mulberry appearance of the superior turbinate.

questions.correct_answer: C. Hypertrophic rhinitis is characterized by turbinate hypertrophy due to submucosal fibrosis and is most commonly treated with turbinectomy.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hypertrophic rhinitis is characterized by turbinate hypertrophy due to submucosal fibrosis and is most commonly treated with turbinectomy.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: Rhinitis medicamentosa is caused by prolonged use of nasal decongestants (e.g., oxymetazoline, xylometazoline), not antihistamines.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. False: The treatment for rhinitis medicamentosa involves stopping the use of nasal decongestants and using systemic and local steroids for a short duration, not increasing the dose of nasal decongestants.
  • • Option B. False:
  • • Option C. True: Hypertrophic rhinitis results from prolonged chronic simple rhinitis leading to submucosal fibrosis and turbinate hypertrophy, typically treated with turbinectomy due to the fibrotic pathology.
  • • Option C. True:
  • • Option D. False: Hypertrophic rhinitis typically affects the inferior turbinate, not the superior turbinate, and presents with a mulberry appearance.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rhinitis medicamentosa is caused by prolonged use of nasal decongestants, leading to alpha-adrenergic receptor downregulation, and is treated by stopping the decongestant and using systemic and local steroids. Hypertrophic rhinitis involves turbinate hypertrophy due to submucosal fibrosis and is treated with surgical intervention such as turbinectomy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with chronic nasal obstruction and foul-smelling discharge. On examination, the nasal mucosa appears pale with extensive crusting, and the nasal cavity is notably wide. She reports anosmia but is unaware of the foul smell. What is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate initial management?

options.label: A
options.text: Allergic rhinitis; antihistamines and nasal steroids

options.label: B
options.text: Atrophic rhinitis; nasal irrigation and 25% glucose in glycerine paint

options.label: C
options.text: Chronic sinusitis; antibiotics and nasal decongestants

options.label: D
options.text: Nasal polyps; surgical removal and corticosteroids

questions.correct_answer: B. Atrophic rhinitis; nasal irrigation and 25% glucose in glycerine paint
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Atrophic rhinitis; nasal irrigation and 25% glucose in glycerine paint

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: Allergic rhinitis typically presents with itching, sneezing, and clear nasal discharge. The pale mucosa, crusting, and widened nasal cavity with anosmia and foul-smelling discharge are not typical features of allergic rhinitis.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. True: Atrophic rhinitis is characterized by pale mucosa, crusting, widened nasal cavity, and anosmia (merciful anosmia). Initial management includes nasal irrigation to remove crusts and 25% glucose in glycerine paint to inhibit proteolytic organisms.
  • • Option B. True:
  • • Option C. False: Chronic sinusitis would present with purulent discharge, facial pain, and nasal obstruction. The extensive crusting and widened nasal cavity are not typical features.
  • • Option C. False:
  • • Option D. False: Nasal polyps usually cause obstruction and anosmia but do not typically result in pale mucosa with crusting and widened nasal cavity seen in atrophic rhinitis.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atrophic rhinitis is characterized by pale nasal mucosa, extensive crusting, widened nasal cavity, anosmia, and foul-smelling discharge, and is initially managed with nasal irrigation and 25% glucose in glycerine paint.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with watery nasal discharge, sneezing fits, nasal obstruction, and itching. She reports a family history of similar symptoms. On examination, she has a transverse nasal crease and dark circles under her eyes. What is the most likely diagnosis, and which treatment is appropriate for her condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Vasomotor rhinitis; decongestants and saline irrigation

options.label: B
options.text: Allergic rhinitis; antihistamines and topical steroid sprays

options.label: C
options.text: Non-allergic rhinitis with eosinophilia syndrome (NARES); antibiotics and nasal decongestants

options.label: D
options.text: Chronic sinusitis; antibiotics and nasal steroids

questions.correct_answer: B. Allergic rhinitis; antihistamines and topical steroid sprays
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Allergic rhinitis; antihistamines and topical steroid sprays

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: Vasomotor rhinitis does not present with the allergic signs such as a transverse nasal crease and dark circles under the eyes. It is usually treated with decongestants and saline irrigation.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. True: The patient's symptoms and physical findings, including a transverse nasal crease (allergic salute) and dark circles under the eyes (allergic shiners), are consistent with allergic rhinitis. Treatment includes antihistamines (e.g., levocetirizine) and topical steroid sprays (e.g., fluticasone).
  • • Option B. True:
  • • Option C. False: NARES presents with nasal eosinophilia but without the classic allergic signs. It is treated differently and does not typically require antibiotics unless there is a secondary bacterial infection.
  • • Option C. False:
  • • Option D. False: Chronic sinusitis involves prolonged inflammation of the sinuses and typically presents with purulent nasal discharge, facial pain, and pressure, which are not described in this patient's case.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Allergic rhinitis is characterized by IgE-mediated immune response causing symptoms such as watery nasal discharge, sneezing, nasal obstruction, and itching, along with physical signs like allergic salute and allergic shiners. Treatment includes antihistamines, topical steroid sprays, and other medications to manage symptoms and inflammation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man from a coastal area presents with blood-tinged nasal discharge and nasal stuffiness. On examination, a polypoidal, pink to purple mass that bleeds on touch is observed in the nasal cavity. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the recommended treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Nasal polyps; corticosteroids and surgical removal

options.label: B
options.text: Rhinosporidiosis; diathermy excision with base cauterisation and Dapsone

options.label: C
options.text: Allergic rhinitis; antihistamines and nasal steroids

options.label: D
options.text: Chronic sinusitis; antibiotics and nasal irrigation

questions.correct_answer: B. Rhinosporidiosis; diathermy excision with base cauterisation and Dapsone
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rhinosporidiosis; diathermy excision with base cauterisation and Dapsone

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: Nasal polyps do not typically present with a strawberry-like appearance and bleeding on touch. The treatment for nasal polyps includes corticosteroids and surgical removal.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. True: Rhinosporidiosis, caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, presents with a leafy, polypoidal, pink to purple mass that bleeds on touch. The recommended treatment is diathermy excision with base cauterisation and Dapsone.
  • • Option B. True:
  • • Option C. False: Allergic rhinitis presents with symptoms like sneezing, nasal congestion, and clear rhinorrhea but does not include a polypoidal, bleeding mass.
  • • Option C. False:
  • • Option D. False: Chronic sinusitis presents with persistent sinus inflammation and purulent nasal discharge but does not include a polypoidal, bleeding mass.
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rhinosporidiosis is caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with a polypoidal, pink to purple mass that bleeds on touch. The recommended treatment includes diathermy excision with base cauterisation and Dapsone.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with unilateral nasal obstruction, discharge, and occasional nosebleeds. On examination, there is a mass in the middle meatus on the lateral wall. Imaging reveals the extent of the lesion, and biopsy confirms the diagnosis. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the treatment of choice?

options.label: A
options.text: Nasal polyps; corticosteroids and surgical removal

options.label: B
options.text: Inverted papilloma; medial maxillectomy

options.label: C
options.text: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma; radiation therapy

options.label: D
options.text: Chronic sinusitis; antibiotics and nasal irrigation

questions.correct_answer: B. Inverted papilloma; medial maxillectomy
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Inverted papilloma; medial maxillectomy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: Nasal polyps typically do not present with epistaxis or orbital symptoms. Corticosteroids and surgical removal are treatments for nasal polyps.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. True: Inverted papilloma, also known as transitional cell papilloma or Schneiderian papilloma, presents with unilateral nasal obstruction, discharge, and epistaxis. It is commonly located in the middle meatus on the lateral wall. The treatment of choice is medial maxillectomy.
  • • Option B. True:
  • • Option C. False: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma typically presents with a mass in the nasopharynx, not the middle meatus, and is primarily treated with radiation therapy.
  • • Option C. False:
  • • Option D. False: Chronic sinusitis presents with persistent sinus inflammation and purulent nasal discharge but does not typically present with a mass in the middle meatus.
  • • Option D. False:

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with unilateral, foul-smelling nasal discharge. Which of the following statements is true regarding potential causes and management?

options.label: A
options.text: Nasal myiasis should be suspected, and treatment involves nasal irrigation with saline.

options.label: B
options.text: A foreign body in the nose should be excluded, and rounded bodies can be removed by forceps.

options.label: C
options.text: Nasal synechiae are common in children with such symptoms and are treated by antibiotics.

options.label: D
options.text: General anesthesia with a cuffed endotracheal tube is used for removal in uncooperative children.

questions.correct_answer: D. General anesthesia with a cuffed endotracheal tube is used for removal in uncooperative children.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) General anesthesia with a cuffed endotracheal tube is used for removal in uncooperative children.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: Nasal myiasis involves maggots in the nose, and treatment typically involves chloroform water or turpentine oil, not saline irrigation.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. False: A foreign body in the nose should indeed be excluded, but rounded bodies are best removed by a blunt hook, not forceps.
  • • Option B. False:
  • • Option C. False: Nasal synechiae are adhesions that form within the nasal cavity, often due to surgery or trauma, and are treated by separating the opposing surfaces with a silastic or cellophane sheet, not antibiotics.
  • • Option C. False:
  • • Option D. True: In babies and uncooperative children, general anesthesia with a cuffed endotracheal tube is used for the removal of foreign bodies.
  • • Option D. True:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of unilateral, foul-smelling nasal discharge in children, a foreign body must be excluded. In uncooperative children, general anesthesia with a cuffed endotracheal tube is used for safe removal.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the anatomy and function of the paranasal sinuses?

options.label: A
options.text: The maxillary sinus is the last to develop and is rarely infected.

options.label: B
options.text: The frontal sinus opens into the superior meatus through the frontal recess.

options.label: C
options.text: The ethmoid sinuses are divided into anterior and posterior groups by the ground lamella.

options.label: D
options.text: The sphenoid sinus is the most commonly infected sinus and is divided into three types of pneumatisation: conchal, presellar, and postsellar.

questions.correct_answer: C. The ethmoid sinuses are divided into anterior and posterior groups by the ground lamella.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The ethmoid sinuses are divided into anterior and posterior groups by the ground lamella.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. False: The maxillary sinus is the earliest to develop and is the most common sinus to get infected.
  • • Option A. False:
  • • Option B. False: The frontal sinus opens into the middle meatus through the frontal recess, not the superior meatus.
  • • Option B. False:
  • • Option C. True: The ethmoid sinuses are divided into anterior and posterior groups by the ground lamella.
  • • Option C. True:
  • • Option D. False: The sphenoid sinus is the least commonly infected sinus and is divided into three types of pneumatisation: conchal, presellar, and sellar (most common).
  • • Option D. False:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ethmoid sinuses are divided into anterior and posterior groups by the ground lamella, with the anterior group opening into the middle meatus and the posterior group opening into the superior meatus.
